segment.source: System cryptography Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing (Windows 10)
segment.target: System cryptography Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing (Windows 10)

segment.source: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.
segment.target: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.

segment.source: System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing
segment.target: System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing

segment.source: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.
segment.target: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.

segment.source: The Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 140 is a security implementation that is designed for certifying cryptographic software.
segment.target: The Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 140 is a security implementation that is designed for certifying cryptographic software.

segment.source: Windows implements these certified algorithms to meet the requirements and standards for cryptographic modules for use by departments and agencies of the United States federal government.
segment.target: Windows implements these certified algorithms to meet the requirements and standards for cryptographic modules for use by departments and agencies of the United States federal government.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether the TLS/SSL security provider supports only the FIPS-compliant strong cipher suite known as TLSRSAWITH3DESEDECBCSHA, which means that the provider only supports the TLS protocol as a client computer and as a server, if applicable.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether the TLS/SSL security provider supports only the FIPS-compliant strong cipher suite known as TLSRSAWITH3DESEDECBCSHA, which means that the provider only supports the TLS protocol as a client computer and as a server, if applicable.

segment.source: It uses only the Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES) encryption algorithm for the TLS traffic encryption, only the Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) public key algorithm for the TLS key exchange and authentication, and only the Secure Hash Algorithm version 1 (SHA-1) hashing algorithm for the TLS hashing requirements.
segment.target: It uses only the Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES) encryption algorithm for the TLS traffic encryption, only the Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) public key algorithm for the TLS key exchange and authentication, and only the Secure Hash Algorithm version 1 (SHA-1) hashing algorithm for the TLS hashing requirements.

segment.source: For the EFS service, this policy setting supports the 3DES and Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption algorithms for encrypting file data supported by the NTFS file system.
segment.target: For the EFS service, this policy setting supports the 3DES and Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption algorithms for encrypting file data supported by the NTFS file system.

segment.source: To encrypt file data, by default EFS uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm with a 256-bit key in the Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and later, and it uses a DESX algorithm in Windows XP.
segment.target: To encrypt file data, by default EFS uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm with a 256-bit key in the Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and later, and it uses a DESX algorithm in Windows XP.

segment.source: For encrypting Remote Desktop Services network communication, this policy setting supports only the Triple DES encryption algorithm.
segment.target: For encrypting Remote Desktop Services network communication, this policy setting supports only the Triple DES encryption algorithm.

segment.source: For BitLocker, this policy setting needs to be enabled before any encryption key is generated.
segment.target: For BitLocker, this policy setting needs to be enabled before any encryption key is generated.

segment.source: Recovery passwords created on Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1 and later when this policy is enabled are incompatible with BitLocker on operating systems prior to Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1; BitLocker will prevent the creation or use of recovery passwords on these systems, so recovery keys should be used instead.
segment.target: Recovery passwords created on Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1 and later when this policy is enabled are incompatible with BitLocker on operating systems prior to Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1; BitLocker will prevent the creation or use of recovery passwords on these systems, so recovery keys should be used instead.

segment.source: For use with TLS, set this policy to Enabled.
segment.target: For use with TLS, set this policy to Enabled.

segment.source: Client devices with this policy setting enabled will be unable to communicate through digitally encrypted or signed protocols with servers that do not support these algorithms.
segment.target: Client devices with this policy setting enabled will be unable to communicate through digitally encrypted or signed protocols with servers that do not support these algorithms.

segment.source: Client devices that are connected to the network and do not support these algorithms cannot use servers that require the algorithms for network communications.
segment.target: Client devices that are connected to the network and do not support these algorithms cannot use servers that require the algorithms for network communications.

segment.source: If you enable this policy setting, you must also configure Internet Explorer to use TLS.
segment.target: If you enable this policy setting, you must also configure Internet Explorer to use TLS.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: When this setting is enabled, the Encrypting File System (EFS) service supports only the Triple DES encryption algorithm for encrypting file data.
segment.target: When this setting is enabled, the Encrypting File System (EFS) service supports only the Triple DES encryption algorithm for encrypting file data.

segment.source: By default, the Windows Vista and the Windows Server 2003 implementation of EFS uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) with a 256-bit key.
segment.target: By default, the Windows Vista and the Windows Server 2003 implementation of EFS uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) with a 256-bit key.

segment.source: The Windows XP implementation uses DESX.
segment.target: The Windows XP implementation uses DESX.

segment.source: When this setting is enabled, BitLocker generates recovery password or recovery keys applicable to versions listed in the following:
segment.target: When this setting is enabled, BitLocker generates recovery password or recovery keys applicable to versions listed in the following:

segment.source: Windows 10, Windows 8.1, and Windows Server 2012 R2
segment.target: Windows 10, Windows 8.1, and Windows Server 2012 R2

segment.source: When created on these operating systems, the recovery password cannot be used on other systems listed in this table.
segment.target: When created on these operating systems, the recovery password cannot be used on other systems listed in this table.

segment.source: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.
segment.target: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.

segment.source: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.
segment.target: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.

segment.source: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.
segment.target: When created on these operating systems, the recovery key can be used on other systems listed in this table as well.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Setting and deploying this policy using Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.
segment.target: Setting and deploying this policy using Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.

segment.source: If the Group Policy is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.
segment.target: If the Group Policy is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: You can enable this policy setting to ensure that the device uses the most powerful algorithms that are available for digital encryption, hashing, and signing.
segment.target: You can enable this policy setting to ensure that the device uses the most powerful algorithms that are available for digital encryption, hashing, and signing.

segment.source: Use of these algorithms minimize the risk of compromise of digitally encrypted or signed data by an unauthorized user.
segment.target: Use of these algorithms minimize the risk of compromise of digitally encrypted or signed data by an unauthorized user.

segment.source: Enable the System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing setting.
segment.target: Enable the System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing setting.

segment.source: Client devices that have this policy setting enabled cannot communicate by means of digitally encrypted or signed protocols with servers that do not support these algorithms.
segment.target: Client devices that have this policy setting enabled cannot communicate by means of digitally encrypted or signed protocols with servers that do not support these algorithms.

segment.source: Network clients that do not support these algorithms cannot use servers that require them for network communications.
segment.target: Network clients that do not support these algorithms cannot use servers that require them for network communications.

segment.source: For example, many Apache-based Web servers are not configured to support TLS.
segment.target: For example, many Apache-based Web servers are not configured to support TLS.

segment.source: If you enable this setting, you must also configure Internet Explorer® to use TLS.
segment.target: If you enable this setting, you must also configure Internet Explorer® to use TLS.

segment.source: This policy setting also affects the encryption level that is used for the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).
segment.target: This policy setting also affects the encryption level that is used for the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

segment.source: The Remote Desktop Connection tool uses the RDP protocol to communicate with servers that run Terminal Services and client computers that are configured for remote control; RDP connections fail if both devices are not configured to use the same encryption algorithms.
segment.target: The Remote Desktop Connection tool uses the RDP protocol to communicate with servers that run Terminal Services and client computers that are configured for remote control; RDP connections fail if both devices are not configured to use the same encryption algorithms.
